Title.evidence: A multicenter randomized controlled trial was conducted in 6 hospitals in Thailand

Trial_Design.evidence: Patients were randomized to PC (ie, immediately wound closure) or DPC (ie, wound closure at postoperative days 3–5)

Participants.evidence: enrolling patients with gangrenous and ruptured appendicitis

Intervention.evidence: Patients were randomized to PC (ie, immediately wound closure) or DPC (ie, wound closure at postoperative days 3–5)

Objective.evidence: To compare superficial surgical site infection (SSI) rates between delayed primary wound closure (DPC) and primary wound closure (PC) for complicated appendicitis.

Method_Outcome.evidence: Superficial SSI was defined by the Center for Disease Control criteria.

Number_Randomised.evidence: 303 and 304 patients were randomized to PC and DPC groups

Number_Analysed.evidence: 300 and 298 patients in the modified intention-to-treat analysis

Result_Outcome.evidence: The superficial SSI rate was lower in the PC than DPC groups [ie, 7.3% (95% confidence interval 4.4, 10.3) vs 10% (95% CI 6.6, 13.3)] with a risk difference (RD) of −2.7% (−7.1%, 1.9%)
